questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
Disaster Management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: 

  Involves immediate management of mass casualties

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery:

   Involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is most prone to non-union?
questions.solution:
Among the given fractures, proximal scaphoid fractures are most prone to non-union. 

Since the nutrient artery enters the scaphoid near its distal end, proximal fractures are associated with avascular necrosis and non-union. The more proximal the fracture in the scaphoid, the higher the chances of avascular necrosis and non-union.

Certain bones have a relatively limited or watershed blood supply that can potentially get interrupted by fracture.  These include:

  •  Talar neck
  •  Waist of the scaphoid
  •  Proximal metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal
  •  Femoral neck

Fractures in these sites have a higher risk for non-union or development of osteonecrosis.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask is
questions.solution:
The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

A conventional oxygen mask is a simple face mask that is used routinely in hospitals. It covers the nose and mouth of the patient. There are 2 exhalation ports through which the patient exhales carbon dioxide. This mask is held in place with elastic around the back of the head and a metal piece that fits over the nose. It provides 40% to 60% of O2 concentration and delivers O2 at the rate of 6 to 10 L/min.

Conventional oxygen therapy includes all the devices that are used in routine practices. It includes nasal prongs, low-flow nasal cannula, or masks. It is the main supportive treatment administered to patients after planned extubation. 

Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

Important note- If the question is about the maximum flow rate with the conventional oxygen mask, it would be 10L/ min. Whereas if the question is asking about the maximum oxygen flow rate with conventional oxygen therapy, then it would include all the conventionally used devices. Therefore, the answer would be 15L/min.

The structures marked in the above image are as follows: A, Langhan's layer; B, Rohr's layer; C, Nitabuch's layer

The definitive placenta (see image) consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them. The structures in each of these parts are as follows: 

 

Fetal side: Chorionic plate 

  • Amnion
  • Primary (extraembryonic) mesoderm with fetal blood vessels
  • Cytotrophoblast (Langhan's layer) 
  • Syncytiotrophoblast

Maternal side: Basal plate 

  • Stratum spongiosum of decidua basalis containing maternal blood vessels
  • Outer layer of syncytiotrophoblast (Nitabuch’s layer)
  • Outer shell of cytotrophoblast
  • Inner layer of syncytiotrophoblast (Rohr’s fibrinoid stria)

Between basal plate and chorionic plate

  • Intervillous space
  • Maternal blood flowing in the intervillous space
  • Stem villi
  • Fetal blood flowing within the fetal villi

questions.text: Hyperacute graft rejection is commonly seen in the transplants of:-
questions.solution:
Hyperacute graft rejection is seen in the kidney.

Hyperacute rejection:-

Hyperacute rejection occurs usually within the first few hours post-transplantation and is mediated by preformed antibodies against ABO or MHC antigens of the graft. Once the antibodies bind to the transplanted tissues, rejection can be caused either by activation of the complement system, which results in the chemotactic attraction of granulocytes and the triggering of inflammatory circuits, or by ADCC (Antibody-Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity).

Pathological features of hyperacute rejection are the following:

  • This is associated with the formation of massive intravascular platelet aggregates leading to thrombosis, ischemia, and necrosis.
  • The hyperacute rejection episodes are irreversible and invariably results in graft loss. With proper cross-matching techniques, this type of rejection is almost 100% avoidable.
  • The hyperacute rejection by antibodies to all human cellular antigens is the major limitation of xenogeneic transplantation (e.g., pig to human).

questions.text: The treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia is ______.

choices.text: Arsenic trioxide and all transretinoic acid

questions.solution:
Arsenic trioxide and all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA)/tretinoin are used in the treatment of Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)

  • APL is characterized by t(15; 17) and the fusion gene PML-RAR-alpha (promyelocyte-retinoic acid receptor alpha).
  • It is a highly curable subtype of leukemia 
  • Induction.
    • Initial treatment: ATRA + anthracycline (daunorubicin or idarubicin) or cytarabine.

OR

    • ATRA + arsenic trioxide 
  • Consolidation: Post remission anthracycline-based chemotherapy

questions.text: Management of an appendicular mass in appendicitis is _______
questions.solution:
Ochsner–Sherren regimen is indicated for patients with appendicular mass in whom conditions are stable.

The patient's temperature and pulse rate are recorded 4-hourly and adequate fluid balance is maintained. CECT abdomen is done and antibiotic therapy is started. Abscess if present is drained. Improvement is usually seen within 24–48 hours.

Ochsner–Sherren regimen:

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass
 

Other options:

  • Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis.
  • If the patient's condition deteriorates or if there is evidence of peritonitis, laparotomy is performed.
  • Incision and drainage are not done in appendicitis.

questions.text: The terms 'exciting eye' and 'sympathizing eye' are used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The terms 'exciting eye' and 'sympathizing eye' are characteristic of sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. The injured eye is called the 'exciting eye' and the fellow eye which also develops uveitis is called the 'sympathizing eye'. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.

According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are depicted in the image below.

The exciting eye shows features of low-grade uveitis such as ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. The sympathizing eye is usually involved 4-8 weeks later. It has a prodromal stage with photophobia, ciliary congestion, and keratic precipitates. In the fully developed stage, symptoms of acute iridocyclitis supervene.

Prophylactic measures to be taken before the condition sets in include topical or systemic steroids and antibiotics. Early excision of the injured eye is carried out if it cannot be salvaged. Once sympathetic ophthalmitis has already set in, enucleation of the injured eye must be done. Atropine and  immunosuppressants can also be administered. 

Other options:

Option A: Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. It is associated with heterochromia iridis, anterior capsular cataract, pigmentary retinopathy and secondary open-angle glaucoma.

Option B: Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye. Clinical features include the following:

  • Kayser–Fleischer ring- a golden brown ring that occurs due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane
  • Sunflower cataract- copper deposits under the lens's anterior capsule cause sunflower cataracts. It is arranged like a sunflower's petals and has a brilliant golden-green hue.

Option D: Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome is an idiopathic multisystem autoimmune disease featuring inflammation of melanocyte-containing tissues such as the uvea, ear and meninges. It is associated with HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4. It is associated with alopecia, neurological lesions, anterior uveitis and posterior uveitis (Dalen-Fuchs nodules).

questions.text: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with which chromosomal translocation?
questions.solution:
Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8.

The classic t(8;14)(q24;q32) reciprocal translocation results in the transposition of the c-myc proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 with one of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) genes on chromosome 14, which results in activation of the c-myc gene and is considered responsible for tumor proliferation.

As a result, the MYC coding sequence is intact with the loss of regulatory control. The activation of the proto-oncogene leads to overexpression of the MYC protein, which is responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: The nerve of Wrisberg is ______
questions.solution:
The nerve of Wrisberg is the sensory part of the facial nerve.

  • The facial nerve is a mixed nerve having the motor and a sensory root. The latter is also called the nerve of Wrisberg.
  • The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is called Jacobson's nerve.
  • Auricular branch of the vagus (cranial nerve X) is called Arnold’s nerve.

questions.text: By when does the fetal kidney start producing urine?
questions.solution:
Fetal kidneys start producing urine at 12 weeks (8–11 weeks), and by 18 weeks, they produce 7 to 14 mL per day.

Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma contributes to the formation of amniotic fluid during early pregnancy.

Amniotic fluid formation varies with the stage of pregnancy:

  • Early pregnancy: Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma 
  • Second trimester: Extracellular fluid that diffuses through the fetal skin and thus reflects the composition of fetal plasma
  • After 20 weeks: Fetal urine, since keratinization of fetal skin prevents diffusion across the skin

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost can be given in a case of open-angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma.

Latanoprost is a PGF2α analog and it is not associated with systemic side effects like bronchospasm and hence can be given for asthmatic patients. Prostaglandin analogs are the first choice drugs for open-angle glaucoma.

Mechanism of action: It reduces intraocular pressure by altering the ciliary muscle tension and improving the outflow of the aqueous humor.

Advantages of latanoprost:

  • Good efficacy
  • Once-daily application
  • Absence of systemic side effects

Disadvantage: High cost

Adverse effects:

  • Blurring of vision
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes
  • Macular edema can occur especially in aphakic patients.

Other options:

Timolol: It is a non-selective beta-blocker used topically in glaucoma. It is associated with systemic effects by absorption through the nasolacrimal duct and can cause life-threatening bronchospasm in asthmatics and COPD patients. Hence they are not given in asthmatic patients.

Gemeprost: It is a PGE1 analog used for the termination of early preganacy.

Mannitol infusion: It is given for acute congestive glaucoma and not for open-angle glaucoma. It causes decongestion of the eye by its osmotic action.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text:
A patient presented with complaints of chest pain at rest for 6 hours and ECG suggestive of Myocardial Ischemia. Which among the following is used for diagnosis?

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
Measurement of LDH1 is suggestive of MI as it is seen predominantly in the heart.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

  • Normally, serum levels of LDH2 are greater than those of LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1 is more than LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.

  • LDH: A tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (Heart) and M isoform (Muscle)

    • LDH-1: Heart.
    • LDH-2: Blood.
    • LDH-3: Brain, kidney, lungs, spleen, pancreas.
    • LDH-4: Liver and skeletal muscle.
    • LDH-5: Liver and skeletal muscle.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.

The other cardiac biomarkers are:

Troponin T and Troponin I

  • These are the proteins that mediate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletal muscles.
  • They are highly specific for MI.
  • Troponin I is more important than troponin T.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.
  • This makes troponins a superior marker for diagnosing MI in the recent past (late diagnosis).
  • Reinfarction: It is now clear that cardiac troponin (cTn) increases rapidly, even if it is from an abnormal baseline in patients with reinfarction.
  • If the cTn concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction, the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement

Creatine kinase (CK).

  • It is less sensitive than troponins.
  • When cTn is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI.
  • If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and specific.

Myoglobin

  • It is the earliest enzyme to increase after MI.
  • Myoglobin is a protein found in the skeletal and cardiac muscles, which binds oxygen.
  • It is a very sensitive indicator of muscle injury.
  • However, it is not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.
  • The rise in myoglobin can help to determine the size of infarction.

questions.text: A procedure designed to induce feared physiological sensations, but under a controlled circumstance is called?
questions.solution:
Interoceptive exposure is a procedure designed to induce feared physiological sensations under controlled circumstances.

Interoceptive exposure is a form of exposure therapy for the treatment for panic disorder and specific phobias. It is done using an activity that produces similar physiological sensations to the ones that are produced during the panic attack.The purpose is to promote habituation of fear in response to them.

Example: Aerobic exercise to induce rapid heart rate and shortness of breath, Breathing through thin straw produces sensation of not getting enough air.

Other options:

Option B: Imaginal exposure typically involves having the patient close their eyes and imagine feared stimuli.

Option C: In vivo exposure involves helping patients directly confront feared objects, activities, and situations.

Option D: Flooding approach involves repeated and prolonged exposure to fear cues of high intensity without relaxation.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
questions.solution:
Ostium secundum is the most common type of atrial septal defect (ASD), located at mid-inter-atrial septum, in the region of the fossa ovalis.

Other options:

  • Endocardial cushion defect/AV septal defect/AV canal defect consists of contiguous atrial and VSDs with markedly abnormal AV valves. The lesion is common in children with Down syndrome
  • Sinus venosus: high atrial septum, at the junction of superior vena cava and right atrium

questions.text: Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor.

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

It is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous). Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species competitively inhibits tyrosinase and results in hypopigmentation.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’.

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails

Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest concentration in the saliva, under resting conditions?
questions.solution:
The concentration of the bicarbonate is highest in the saliva (50 to 70 mEq/L).

Secretion of ions in saliva:

  • Salivary secretion occurs in two stages.
  • The first stage involves acini, which secrete ptyalin and/or mucin together with some ions. The composition of the ions is similar to that of the extra-cellular fluid.
  • The second stage involves the ducts. As the primary salivary secretion flows through the ducts, two active transport processes occur:
    • Na+ is actively re-absorbed and K+ is actively secreted, in exchange for Na+.
    • HCO3- is secreted by the ductal epithelium into the lumen of the salivary ducts. Some of this secretion occurs by passive exchange of bicarbonate for Cl-.
  • As a result, the Na+ and Cl- concentrations are lower than that of plasma, while K+ and HCO3- concentrations are higher than that of plasma.

Composition of ions:

  • Under resting conditions, the concentrations of Na+ and Cl- in saliva are about 15 mEq/L each, which is 1/7th to 1/10th that of the plasma concentrations.
  • K+ concentration is about 30 mEq/L, which is seven times higher than that of plasma.
  • HCO3- concentration is 50 to 70 mEq/L, which is two to three times higher than that of the plasma.

questions.text: A salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion is _______.
questions.solution:
A salivary gland tumour with a propensity for perineural invasion is adenoid cystic carcinoma.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a slow-growing malignant tumour of major and minor salivary glands. It is composed of both epithelial and myoepithelial cells. It is the second most common malignant tumour of the parotid gland. The histologic types of adenoid cystic carcinoma are tubular, cribriform, and solid. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. 

Adenoid cystic carcinoma has propensity for perineural invasion. Patients will present with slow-growing masses, with the presence of numbness, paraesthesia or pain. Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor, with radiation therapy for the microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: The type of acidosis seen in RTA(Renal tubular acidosis) is

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap  hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis.

questions.solution:
In renal tubular acidosis, there occurs normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis as a result of defective transport of proximal tubular reabsorption of bicarbonate or distal secretion of H+.

Renal tubular acidosis: Refers to a group of disorders in which despite a relatively well-preserved GFR(glomerular filtration rate ), there occurs acidosis because of defects of tubules of kidney to perform normal functions required to maintain acid-base balance.

Types 

  • Type I: Distal RTA, also known as classical RTA
  • Type II: Proximal RTA
  • Type III: Mixed type (extremely rare and it is just a combination of type I and type II)
  • Type IV: Hypoaldosteronism.
